results.name: Triple factorial array, read by antidiagonals, where row n+1 is generated from row n by first removing terms in row n at positions {[m*(m+5)/6], m>=0} and then taking partial sums, starting with all 1's in row 0.
comment: This is the triple factorial variant of Moessner's factorial array described by A125714 and also of the double factorial array A135876. Another very interesting variant is A136217.
formula: Columns 0, 1 and 2 form the triple factorials A007559, A008544 and A032031, respectively. Column 4 equals A024216; column 6 equals A024395.
example: where terms in parenthesis are at positions {[m*(m+5)/6], m>=0}
and are removed before taking partial sums to obtain the next row.
To generate the array, start with all 1's in row 0; from then on,
obtain row n+1 from row n by first removing terms in row n at
positions {[m*(m+5)/6], m>=0} and then taking partial sums.
For example, to generate row 2 from row 1:
remove terms at positions [0,1,2,4,6,8,11,14,17,...] to get:
then take partial sums to obtain row 2:
Continuing in this way will generate all the rows of this array.
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := t[n, k] = Module[{a = 0, m = 0, c = 0, d = 0}, If[n == 0, a = 1, While[d <= k, If[c == Quotient[(m*(m + 5)), 6], m += 1, a += t[n - 1, c]; d += 1]; c += 1]]; a]; Table[t[n - k, k], {n, 0, 9}, {k, 0, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 06 2013, translated from Pari *)
